title: Report on Blunt's claim for an increase of $2 billion for a business transaction with Mexico, Canada
text: The conference reconvened in September to deliberate on the new trade deal with Mexico and Canada. The trade agreement, known as USMCA, has been a hot topic between farmers and politicians over the past year. In a Facebook article published on 13 August, Republican Sun. Roy Blunt endorsed the agreement: "United States exports of agricultural and food products are expected to increase by more than $2 billion annually under USMCA. This business transaction is a win-win for farmers, farm owners and companies in America. A spokesman for Blunt said that the figure came from a report of the United States International Trade Commission, which stated that the Agreement would increase "exports by $2.2 billion (1.1 per cent) when fully implemented." Billions look like a lot. 1.1%, not much. We have decided to consider this allegation. So, what's the deal exactly? The agreement between the United States, Mexico and Canada is a trade agreement that replaces the North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA). Mexico ratified the new agreement in June. In Canada, Parliament introduced the bill in May but insisted on proceeding with the ratification process in tandem with the United States. The trick here is that Canada's ratification window became smaller, with its federal elections on October 21st. If the United States Congress does not move fast enough and Canada does not ratify it before 15 September, it will have to resubmit the agreement to the next Parliament. In the meantime, the fate of the agreement in Congress is dominated by the Democrats of the House of Representatives.
